article.description:
Julius Barnes and his Stanford teammates
have been working all season on their free throw shooting. It
finally paid off.
article.headline: Barnes sets team record by making all 13 free throws
article.linkText: Free-throw practice pays off in Stanford's win over USC
article.story:
STANFORD, Calif. (AP) -- Julius Barnes and his Stanford teammates
have been working all season on their free throw shooting. It
finally paid off.

	   Julius Barnes scored 27 points, including a record-setting
effort from the foul line, as Stanford defeated USC 80-72 Saturday.

	   "This is what we work on every day after practice,'' said
Barnes. "I can't explain why we made all the free throws we did
today. It's all mental. I was fortunate to go to the line as often
as I did and put them down. I guess we got into a good rhythm.''

	   Josh Childress had his sixth double-double of the season with 14
points and a career-high 15 rebounds as the Cardinal (14-5, 5-2 in
the Pac-10) beat the Trojans for the first time in four games. Matt
Lottich added 22 points, one off his career high.

	   "This is one of our better efforts of the year,'' said Stanford
coach Mike Montgomery. "Julius got us off to a good start
offensively and Josh was huge on the boards.''

	   Desmon Farmer scored 23 points to lead USC (7-8, 3-4), which has
lost four of its last five. Rory O'Neil added 14.

	   Stanford entered the game as the Pac-10's worst free throw
shooting team but responded with a 16-of-18 effort in the final
five minutes, snapping a 62-62 tie to give the Cardinal their fifth
win in six games. Barnes was 10-of-10 from the free-throw line over
the final 11:18 and established a Maples Pavilion record by making
all 13 of his foul shots.

	   "Every game we seem to come up short when it comes to doling
out the fouls,'' said USC coach Henry Bibby. "We cannot get a look
down the stretch. They get two buckets in the last 11 minutes and
the rest were free throws. I've never seen it that bad. The refs
told me we were being overly aggressive. Sometimes it's just a
lesson we have to take.''

	   Stanford's Justin Davis, the Pac-10's leading rebounder,
returned to action after missing the past five games with a
sprained left knee.

	   Tempers flared early in the second half after USC's Nick Curtis
fouled Stanford's Rob Little less than three minutes into the
second half. Little pushed Curtis and the two had to be separated.
Both players were assessed a technical foul, and both eventually
fouled out.

	   The Trojans drew within 45-44 on a Derrick Craven drive less
than a minute later. O'Neil's 3-pointer with 4:52 remaining tied
the game at 62.

	   "It was frustrating for us because we were right there at the
end,'' said Farmer. "We should have taken command but we didn't.
Our execution wasn't very good.''

	   The Cardinal made 10 of their first 14 shots, a direct contrast
to Thursday's 52-51 victory over UCLA when Stanford missed nine of
its first 12 attempts.

	   Barnes, who was 2-of-8 from the field in Thursday's game,
connected on five of his first six shots with a variety of
3-pointers, driving layups and slam dunks. His effort sparked an
11-0 run and helped Stanford open a 25-14 lead with 11:37 left in
the first half.

	   USC rallied the rest of the way and pulled within 40-33 by
halftime.
